title: The Complete Startup Playbook for B2B Pricing

rawLines.text: My name is Macy Mills and I'm a business
development partner at A16Z Speedrun.
I've worked in B2B sales, revenue, and
partnerships for over a decade. I like
to come up with new ways to scale
revenue. In this video, we will explore
various B2B business models, common
pricing mistakes, and strategies for
setting the right price point. Let's
dive in.
[Music]
In a world where PLG or productled
growth continues to gain momentum, the
lines begin to blur between B2B and B
TOC, understanding the distinction for
your business is crucial for startups
because it will affect decisions such as
product development and pricing
strategy. One of the ways that I like to
differentiate between B2B PLG versus B
TOC is actually the collaboration piece
of it. If you're building a B2B PLG
product and you're asking yourself, is
this actually a B TOC product? It's a
fair question. One key differentiator in
my mind is that B2B products often
foster collaboration. That means that I
can jump into the product and have value
while working with somebody else. A good
example of collaboration in a B2B PLG
app is Slack, Notion, or even Miro and
Figma. A helpful rule of thumb is that
if a product is generating less than
$10,000 ACV or annual contract value,
you may be in the BTOC business.
However, this is not a strict rule as
there are always exceptions in different
industries. One other distinction worth
mentioning is PLG versus tops down
sales. Tops down sales is the
traditional sales motion. You're picking
up the phone, you're creating leads,
you're following through a sales funnel
until you close deals. PLG is more
organic. And to be honest, I've always
personally loved making money while you
sleep. But it can take months or more
likely years to build a successful PLG
product. A lot of startups think you
have to pick one or the other. Am I
productled growth? Do I focus on organic
verality or am I a tops down sales
motion? In reality, you can have both
motions running simultaneously. And that
gives you the most opportunity for
growth on both sides of the market.
Understanding your customer and
effective selling strategies is crucial
to driving success for your business.
Now, let's dive into some various
business
models. There are several business
models to structure your B2B pricing.
The right one depends on your product,
your cost, and your ICP or ideal
customer profile. Different business
models work for different needs, so it's
all about finding the right fit for you
and your audience. Here are the four
most common B2B business models. Number
one, usage or consumptionbased pricing.
Usage or consumptionbased pricing is
basically pay as you go. You charge the
customer based on how much they consume.
This has become popular with cloud
providers such as AWS, GCP, and
Microsoft Azure, but it's gaining
momentum as a business model because of
AI costs. If your product is tied to an
API or cloud services or probably more
AI products, your cost is going to
increase exponentially as users tend to
use your product more. An easy way to
get around that is with usage or
consumption based pricing where you
charge the user based on API calls or
credits or tokens, for example. So,
imagine you're playing a video game and
the backend servers are connecting you
to one other player. There's only two
players in this game, so you can imagine
that the compute cost isn't that high.
Now, open that game up to thousands or
even millions of players at the same
time. You can imagine the back-end cost
for scaling something of that magnitude
is much higher. This is how usagebased
pricing tends to make more money over
time and scales as their customers
scale. This allows you to balance your
cost of the infrastructure with what
you're charging and the revenue that
you're getting from customers. AI has a
huge infrastructure and compute cost and
hopefully in the future we'll see some
of those costs going down, not up.
However, it's driving an increase of
consumptionbased pricing for products
that were maybe previously
subscription-based pricing. If you're
building an AI product, you know that
your AI infrastructure costs are now
starting to compete with your cloud
costs for taking up the most of your
margin. That's something that you need
to take into consideration when you're
setting up your business model. Number
two, subscription or userbased pricing.
This is the SAS classic. Monthly or
annual recurring subscriptions drive
predictability for not only you but also
your customers. While user-based pricing
and subscriptions are technically not
synonyms, I believe they go hand in
hand. Lots of subscription-based pricing
have a number of users that you're
allowed to use or even price by the
number of users where most of userbased
pricing is actually subscription as
well. A couple of examples for
subscriptionbased pricing where it is a
pay for user is actually Slack. Slack
requires you to pay per user on a
subscription basis where companies such
as ASA and Salesforce offer a tiered
system where you're able to have a
certain number of users per tier. In my
opinion, it's hard to offer unlimited
amount of users because you're capping
your ability to upsell customers in the
future. If you give them unlimited
users, they may not need to come back to
you to buy more seats or to upgrade
their tier to the next level that allows
them to have more users. Number three,
projectbased pricing. This is pricing
based on a specific project or a
specific amount of time that you'll be
working with a customer. This is quite
common when it comes to consultancy or
services or professional support on a
one-off basis. Typically, these are a
design partnership where they're working
with a customer on specific features for
the platform that they're working on,
perhaps moving features up on their road
map or giving them specific features for
their use case. Now, this can be great
because you'll show a revenue bump
pretty early on in the customer life
cycle. However, it can also be
challenging because some of these
customers can become extremely needy and
you're not having a repeatable play that
you can go out and do again and again.
So, I always urge founders to switch
over from projectbased pricing or
services-based pricing as quickly as
possible to something that's a bit more
scalable and a bit more predictable for
them to talk to their investors about.
Number four, sitebased pricing. This
pricing is typically based on being
locked to a specific location or a
specific office of a companies and so
for example the product is only
available for folks that work in the San
Francisco office. This used to be a lot
more common and software products for
businesses. However, as the workforce
becomes more distributed and remote
working becomes the norm, sitebased
pricing continues to lose popularity and
it's not something that I typically
recommend for our founders. It's common
to see a blend of these different
business models. And for example, I
think blending number one, usage or
consumption based pricing with number
two, subscription or userbased pricing
is a really good option, especially for
AI startups. This allows you to get some
of the predictability that you'll find
from subscriptionbased pricing with some
of the upside that you'll find with
usage or consumption based pricing. Now,
you'll have to do all of the
spreadsheets to figure out what the
exact numbers are that work for you and
your user base and your ideal customer
profile. However, I tend to think of
those two as good ingredients to start
to make a really good business model
recipe. One other thing to note is a
common pricing strategy across all the
different business models is tiering.
Tiering allows you to drive different
users and different ICPs into different
tiers based on what products or services
they specifically need. Most commonly
tiers are decided by feature
differentiation. So imagine you have
three different tiers on the page. A
starter pack, a company pack, and an
enterprise pack. And each of those may
have a certain number of users included
within the tier. That way, you're still
pricing based on a tier, but you're
giving a certain amount of users per
tier. However, this is not the only way
to do tiering, and we'll discuss that
more in the next section.
Let's first talk about what not to do
when it comes to B2B pricing and
business models because let's be honest,
missteps here are common. Number one,
don't sell yourself short. I've worked
with countless founders that have closed
their first deal at $100, $200, $1,000.
And while all of that is exciting to get
your first check, your software is worth
so much more. It's okay to price low on
your first few deals, but you don't want
to build a habit out of it. You can
start to feel comfortable in these low
price points. Wow, I closed that deal in
a very short amount of time. I'm closing
it faster than my other founder friends.
That can be great, but again, don't sell
yourself short. You have the opportunity
to price based on what the market will
pay. And so, keep testing and
validating. Each time a customer says
yes to a price is a confirmation that
your pricing is either correct or maybe
even too low. Until you start hearing no
consistently from your customers, you're
still pricing too low. Number two, don't
ignore market research and customer
feedback. You should still be looking
into the market at your closest comp to
see how your competitors or even
semicompetitors are pricing their
products. What's even more important
than market research at this crucial
early stage of your startup is customer
feedback. Pay close attention to what
they're saying and what they're not
saying. If your customer isn't asking
you questions about implementation or
setup success, how seriously are they
really taking your product? Even if you
don't have an exact competitor, there's
someone who's selling to your ideal
customer profile and even working in the
same area as you are. Number three,
don't over complicate your pricing.
Simplicity and transparency are key.
Your customers are just like you. They
want something that's as easy to
understand as possible. The more factors
that you involve, the more complicated
you make it, the more difficult it will
be to get the customer to say yes. Try
to break it down as simple as you can so
that you can get that customer to yes as
quickly as possible. You're going to
have to do a lot of back-end
spreadsheeting no matter what you decide
on. And so fall back there to figure out
those margin or revenue questions and
leave the consumerf facing part to be as
simple as possible. Number four, pricing
tiers based on self-declared data. When
I'm talking to founders, I generally
advise to not price your product based
on anything that's self-declared or hard
to track. I had this experience
firsthand, which is why I often give
this advice. In a previous role, I was
selling a product which we'll call Wet
Brush. I knew that I had to pick up the
phone and talk to every single customer
to find out what's their project budget,
how many platforms do they plan to
launch on, and many other details. I had
to know all of these details before I
could even give them a price point. If
you're building tiers based on these
self-declared things, you're actually
leaving the onus on the customer to
figure out how much they owe you. Your
project budget is sometimes dynamic. I
don't know about you, but I've I've gone
off budget on a couple of projects in my
time, and I think that's pretty common.
And so, what happens if the budget
changes and then suddenly you have to go
back to the customer and charge them
less or more? This leads to the next big
pricing mistake. Number five, don't set
up pricing that uses compliance as a
sales play. So, if you're setting up
these arbitrary tiers, which I told you
not to in the last tip, I mean, come on,
really? You'll basically again be always
chasing customers to ensure that their
data is accurate. This drives the
motivation on the salespeople to try to
easily cash their commission check with
compliance deals. It's also not the
nicest way to start a conversation. Hey,
your data is wrong. You lied to me. You
owe me more money. Wouldn't you rather
your salespeople were spending their
time selling to new customers or
upselling your current customers rather
than running around trying to get
customers into compliance because you
chose self-proclaimed data as a tier.
Now that we've covered all the things
not to do, here's how to price like a
pro and drive B2B
growth. I truly believe that pricing is
not oneizefits-all. I spend my time
working with founders of Speedrun,
helping them decide all the little
details when it comes to the price point
and the business models that they're
going to take their product to market
with. There's a lot of content out there
that tells you exactly how to price down
to a science. But in reality, pricing is
an art and a science. And without
knowing all of the details of your ideal
customer profile, your cost structure,
and what goals you're trying to achieve
with your company, it's difficult to
give you an exact model that's going to
drive the most exponential growth for
your business. Now, while I can't do
that with all of you, I do have a few
universal tips that we can discuss
today. Number one, don't discourage
adoption through your pricing model.
Think about pricing as an invitation,
not a barrier. You want to lower the
barrier to entry so that it's easy for
new users to adopt your product. Me
saying that might make you think that
you should avoid user-based pricing.
That's not what I'm saying. User-based
pricing may still make sense for your
product. Think about a way to make your
pricing as approachable as possible and
make it easy for customers to say yes.
One frictionless way to lower the
barrier to entry is by offering free or
lowcost plans to get people onto your
platform. Once customers see the value,
upselling should become easier. There's
also a concept of a reverse trial where
you start by giving the user all of the
things that you have to offer and then
take them away after a certain amount of
time. Now, this can sound rude, but it's
truly not because you're giving them the
opportunity to see all the features that
your product has to offer and then
allowing them to make the decision for
themsel which feature set is most
important. Number two, discount for
commitment. One way to encourage
adoption is to offer a 10 or 20%
discount if the user will commit to a
year instead of, let's say, a month. As
a user, I'm excited about that $200
savings. As the business owner, you
should be excited about the revenue
predictability. You can offer a similar
type of discount for consumptionbased
pricing. The way that this typically
works is that you offer a certain amount
of tokens or credits upfront. The more
the customer will commit to you, the
cheaper the tokens will be on a perunit
basis. This is a great way to again
drive more predictability for your
business while offering a discount to
your users. Number three, simplify and
scale with tiered pricing. If you've
ever bought a product before, you've
probably seen tier based pricing. The
most common use case of this is in the
subscription or userbased pricing where
the more you pay, the more features you
get. One thing I urge founders to
consider is not having too many tiers in
order to drive confusion with users and
offer too many options. If you have more
than three, maximum four tiers, you're
probably overdoing it. One way to
consider your tier-based system is to
consider your ICP. Do you have the right
pricing for each ideal customer profile?
Maybe you're thinking about a hobbyist
all the way up to an enterprise that may
have thousands of users using your tool.
Think about how to simplify as much as
possible while giving yourself a path
for upsell and expansion
[Music]
revenue. In terms of picking the right
actual price point, test it out. You
won't know how much customers are
willing to pay until you throw some
numbers at them and get their reaction.
As your product matures and you add more
features, as well as getting more
feedback, your ICP may completely
change. And that's okay as long as
you're following it through the process
and understanding exactly who it is at
every point in time. You'll be able to
test your pricing with that audience to
ensure that you're striking the right
price point. Therefore, I tend to think
of valuebased pricing as a strategy. Not
only that, but a strategy that I would
look to incorporate later on in your
life cycle. If you're a preede founder,
you're so early within your product
maturity. You don't have case studies to
build from. You don't have those numbers
that will help drive that sale and the
next one after that. Now, you might not
hear this from other podcasts, videos,
etc. But I feel confident that without
valuebased pricing, you'll still be able
to get to a business model that's
scalable and successful for your
business.
[Music]
Okay, so you've decided your business
model. You figured out your pricing.
You're either on the phone or you put
some pricing on your website, which can
be really exciting, but also scary, and
you're trying to figure out if it's
truly working. Let's talk about some
ways that you can measure the success of
your new pricing and business model.
What early metrics will your investors
care about to see if it's working or
not? Number one, number of paying
customers. You're out here, you picked
the price, you're you're selling, and
you've closed your first customer.
Congratulations. That's a huge moment.
You know what's even more exciting and
scary is going from one to five
customers and five to 30 customers.
Tracking how quickly you are acrewing
new customers is also crucial as this
can show your investors how quickly
you're scaling. It's always a good thing
if your customer acquisition rate is
increasing. And remember, it's not just
quantity here, but it's also quality.
Going back to those ICPs, are the
customers that you're closing that are
paying you and hopefully a scalable,
predictable way, are those truly your
ICPs, are those the customers that
you're hoping to close over and over
again that are going to take you from 30
customers to a,000 customers and even
more? Ensuring you're understanding that
quality versus just quantity is another
key to success. Number two, ARR or ACV.
ARR stands for annual recurring revenue.
and ACV stands for annual contract
value. These are both great metrics to
track how well your pricing is working.
ARR tends to make the most sense when
you're looking at those
subscriptionbased or userbased models
that we talked about, while annual
contract value might make more sense if
you're looking at some of the more
bespoke business models, especially at
the beginning of your company life
cycle. Overall, any form of traction
showing an increase of revenue on a
month-to-month or quarter-to- quarter
basis is going to be great news for you
and your investors. Number three, length
of sales cycle. Determine how long it's
taking you to get to closed one. This
will help you determine if you're
pricing correctly. Keep a track on it
over time and ensure that it's getting
shorter, not longer. If you are at the
preede or seed stage, I imagine you're
doing mostly founderled sales. Ensure
that the length of the sales cycle is
based on your pricing and business model
and not external factors such as a
conference that you went to that slowed
you down. This is the part where you
have to be really honest with yourself.
Are you following up in a timely manner?
Is this behind because I went on a
family vacation? Probably not cuz you're
a founder and you probably don't get
family vacations. But like just saying a
little bit later on when you have more
data behind you, two other metrics that
I encourage you to think about are churn
rate and net revenue retention. With
churn rate, you're finding out, are
customers leaving your product or are
they renewing? Now, in most PLG motions,
you can expect a 25% churn rate without
being concerned. That may have something
to do with the value equation and the
fact that the customers aren't seeing
the value that they're putting in when
it comes to the cost. Churn is going to
be something that investors are going to
look closely at. Ensure that you're
tracking it and also doing exit
interviews with customers who decided to
not work with your product any longer.
This will help you better assess in the
future how to get your retention rates
up and your churn rates down. Net
revenue retention. Net revenue retention
measures the percentage of recurring
revenue from your current users, whether
they've downgraded, upgraded, or
expanded, not counting for new revenue
from brand new users. It's a health
metric that allows you to see what's
going on with a specific cohort of
users. It reflects how well the company
is retaining and expanding its current
user base. Monitor this monthly and
quarterly to start until you can get to
an annual net revenue retention rate.
Let's do an easy NRR formula. Let's say
your per customer per month price of
your product is $1,000 and you have five
customers at the beginning of the month.
So, your starting revenue at the
beginning of the month is $5,000. Let's
say that one customer upgrades their
plan, spending an additional
$500. However, the second customer
churns, so you've lost
$1,000. The third one downgrades,
reducing their plan, lowering their
spend by $300. The two remaining
customers continue paying $1,000 each.
Let's break that down. You started with
$5,000. You got $500 in upsell revenue,
$300 in downgrade revenue, and minus
$1,000 from your churned customer. So,
the total end of your month revenue is
$4,200. Net revenue retention formula is
revenue at the end of the period, so
$4,200 divided by the revenue at the
start of the period or $5,000. Times
that by 100, and you get your net
revenue retention over the period, which
84% NRR means that the company has
retained 84% of its starting revenue for
that month after accounting for those
upsells, downgrades, and churns that we
discussed. Let me give you some
benchmarks for NRR. Outstanding NRR is
greater than 120%. That means that most
of your customers are probably upselling
or expanding. An average NR is 90% to
99%. You're technically losing money on
a cohort basis, but if your new customer
revenue is high enough to sustain this,
it could be okay. Less than 90%
typically means that you have a churn
problem or an expansion problem where
too many users are churning or you're
not expanding enough. Pricing isn't just
a number, it's a strategy. Start with a
model that makes the most sense to you.
Be flexible to iterate as you grow and
avoid the common mistakes that we talked
about today. What kinds of challenges
are you facing with scaling your
business? Drop us a comment below and
we'll do our best to answer in a future
video. Welcome to Speedrun founders like
you. You. I'm talking to you and you.
I'm also talking to you since
joining. You good over there? Are you
Are you regretting this yet? Well,
thanks so much for sticking around with
me. I have to get back to solving more
problems such as the cold start
problem. I've always wanted to say like
and subscribe. Do you swipe up now? Is
this the part where you swipe up and
like and subscribe me? Like and
subscribe. A6Z speedrun.
